screening_results.reason: The study uses tensor-based morphometry (TBM) to assess whole-brain structural differences, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration as required. Although it includes an adult PTSD group and a healthy control group (satisfying sample criteria) and reports whole-brain TBM results, the inclusion criteria specifically mandate VBM methods. TBM is a different morphometric technique and therefore falls under the exclusion criterion for studies using non-voxel-based morphometry methods. Consequently, the study does not meet the required imaging-method inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although the study includes adult PTSD and trauma-exposed control soldier groups, it does not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. Methods report surface-based cortical thickness (CIVET vertex- and lobe-based analyses) and region segmentation/volumetry via MAGeT (subcortical and cerebellar ROIs). No whole-brain VBM results or coordinate-based between-group VBM contrasts are reported. Therefore it fails the required inclusion criterion of reporting at least one whole-brain VBM result comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: adult sample (ages 18–50) with three groups (PTSD, trauma-exposed controls, healthy controls); MRI T1-weighted acquisition and voxel‑based morphometry (VBM) analysis; reports whole‑brain VBM between-group contrasts (PTSD vs HC and PTSD vs TC) with coordinate/tabled results and figures; not limited to ROI-only, longitudinal, treatment-only, or non-PTSD trauma studies. Results include coordinate-based whole-brain findings comparing PTSD to both control groups, so it is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes adult combat-exposed veterans with PTSD and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group and reports whole-brain vertex-wise analyses, it does NOT use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The paper reports surface-based cortical thickness measures (FreeSurfer) and vertex-wise cortical thickness results rather than VBM coordinate-based contrasts. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM MRI methods and coordinate-based whole-brain VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or unexposed controls.

This study used whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM-DARTEL) of gray matter volume obtained with MRI and reports whole-brain between-group contrasts (PTSD vs healthy controls and PTSD vs other patient groups) with corrected cluster-level results and peak coordinates. The sample includes an adult PTSD group (Wenchuan earthquake survivors) and a trauma-unexposed healthy control group, satisfying the requirement of a PTSD group plus at least one comparison group (trauma-unexposed controls). Results are whole-brain (FWE-corrected) and coordinate-based findings are described, not limited to ROIs. The study is not a treatment-only or ROI-only paper and participants are adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study does not use whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports manual region-of-interest segmentation of the habenula (ROI volumetry) rather than VBM analyses and provides no whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group contrasts. Additionally, the comparison groups are PTSD patients vs. trauma-unexposed healthy controls only (no trauma-exposed non-PTSD group). Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criteria requiring MRI VBM measures and whole-brain voxelwise results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls.

This study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) using MRI and compares a chronic PTSD group (n=12) to a trauma-exposed control group (miners without PTSD, n=14). Adults only (males 18–49) were included. The paper presents whole-brain VBM results (between-group ANOVAs and post-hoc two-sample t-tests with Alphasim correction) describing regional gray matter volume differences for PTSD vs. trauma-exposed controls and PTSD vs. symptoms-improved survivors. It is not an ROI-only study, does not focus solely on treatment/longitudinal effects, and provides between-group voxel-based comparisons relevant to the review objective. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria (VBM whole-brain results, PTSD group plus trauma-exposed comparison, adult sample) and does not violate exclusion criteria.

Although the study used whole-brain voxel-based morphometry on MRI in PTSD patients, the sample included only PTSD participants (n=59) and the reported between-group comparisons are within PTSD subgroups (dissociative subtype vs non-dissociative). The paper does not include or report any between-group VBM contrasts comparing PTSD patients to trauma-exposed non-PTSD controls or to trauma-unexposed healthy controls. Therefore it fails the required inclusion criterion of having at least one PTSD vs control (trauma-exposed or unexposed) whole-brain VBM comparison.

Although the study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on adult participants and included a PTSD group and a trauma-exposed healthy control group, the paper does not report a whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group VBM contrast specifically comparing the PTSD group alone to the trauma-exposed controls (or to trauma-unexposed controls). The primary reported whole-brain between-group result contrasts the combined clinical groups (PTSD + major depression) against controls; PTSD-specific whole-brain coordinates/contrasts are not provided. Thus it fails the requirement to report at least one whole-brain VBM result comparing individuals with PTSD to a suitable comparison group, and does not meet the inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study acquired and preprocessed GMV maps via a VBM pipeline and included adult PTSD, trauma-exposed non-PTSD (TEC), and non-traumatized healthy control groups, it does not report whole-brain, coordinate-based voxel-wise VBM group-comparison results (mass-univariate statistical contrasts) comparing PTSD to TEC or PTSD to HC. The manuscript uses GMV maps as features for multivariate SVM classification and presents SVM discrimination-weight maps (thresholded weights) rather than voxel-wise VBM statistical comparisons with coordinates/p-values. Therefore it fails the requirement to report at least one whole-brain VBM between-group result; it reports multivariate classification/discrimination maps only, which do not satisfy the review’s inclusion criterion for VBM group-comparison results.

This is a longitudinal treatment study of 20 male soldiers with combat-related PTSD randomized to therapy vs waiting-list; no trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy control group is included. Although MRI VBM preprocessing was used, the reported analyses focus on region-of-interest (hippocampus and amygdala) rather than whole-brain VBM comparisons, and the primary outcomes are treatment/longitudinal effects. The review requires at least one whole-brain VBM between-group contrast comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls; this study does not provide such coordinate-based whole-brain results and is thus ineligible.

This study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on MRI data (VBM5/SPM5) to examine gray matter volume. The sample includes an adult PTSD group (N=15) and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD control group (N=17). The paper reports whole-brain VBM between-group contrasts comparing PTSD vs. traumatized controls (NS > S and S > NS) with coordinate-based results and cluster-level statistics provided in Table 3 and described in the text. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (VBM of GMV, PTSD and trauma-exposed comparison group, whole-brain voxel-wise results reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used voxel-based morphometry (SPM8 with DARTEL) to compare gray matter volume between 21 male combat veterans with PTSD and 20 trauma-exposed veterans without PTSD (adult sample). The paper reports whole-brain VBM between-group results (controls > PTSD in left middle occipital cortex and other regions) at an uncorrected threshold (P<0.001) and summarizes VBM results in tables; although findings did not survive FWE correction, whole-brain coordinate-based results are provided. The design meets inclusion criteria: VBM of gray matter, inclusion of a PTSD group and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group, and reporting of whole-brain between-group VBM results. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not treatment/longitudinal-only, adult participants). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study uses automated subcortical volumetry (FreeSurfer segmentation) and reports region-based volumes and GWAS associations, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It does not present whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts (PTSD vs controls). Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring MRI VBM (whole-brain voxel-wise) results reported with coordinate-based findings.

Although the study used whole-brain VBM of gray matter and included participants with PTSD and trauma-exposed non-PTSD veterans, it did not report any between-group voxelwise contrasts comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls. The analyses focused on within-subject voxelwise regressions relating symptom severity (CAPS) and other continuous measures to gray matter volume. The review requires at least one coordinate-based whole-brain between-group VBM contrast (PTSD vs trauma-exposed or controls). Therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This study does not meet the VBM requirement. Although it uses structural MRI in adult PTSD and control groups (current PTSD, remitted PTSD, trauma-exposed controls), analyses are based on FreeSurfer-derived cortical thickness and group-level structural covariance/graph-theory centrality measures, not voxel-based morphometry of gray matter volume/concentration. The paper does not report whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion that the study measure and report VBM results (whole-brain, coordinate-based) and must be excluded.

This study does not meet the imaging modality requirement and lacks the required comparison groups. It uses diffusion MRI (free-water imaging) reporting fractional anisotropy and mean diffusivity (microstructural dMRI), not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. Additionally, the sample includes only individuals with current PTSD (subdivided into PTSD-only and PTSD+TBI); there is no trauma-exposed non-PTSD group nor a trauma-unexposed healthy control group, and no whole-brain VBM coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD to those comparison groups. Therefore it fails the VBM measurement and sample/comparator inclusion criteria.

Study uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume with MRI; includes an adult PTSD group (n=91) and an unexposed healthy control group (n=201); reports whole-brain VBM comparisons (PTSD vs HC included within diagnosis-specific contrasts and in the transdiagnostic inclusive mask) with coordinate-based results (bilateral putamen clusters) surviving whole-brain FWE correction. Not ROI-only, not longitudinal/treatment only, and includes required between-group contrast (PTSD vs trauma-unexposed controls). Therefore meets all inclusion criteria.

The study uses surface-based cortical thickness measurements (FreeSurfer) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The meta-analysis requires VBM voxel-wise results (coordinate-based) comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Although the sample includes PTSD and comparison groups, no whole-brain VBM results are reported. Therefore the study does not meet the required imaging modality criterion and must be excluded.

This study does not meet the core imaging-method inclusion criteria. It uses atlas-based regional volumetry (multi-atlas segmentation of hippocampus and amygdala; regional ROI volumes) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter concentration/volume. No whole-brain voxelwise VBM analyses or coordinate-based between-group VBM results are reported; comparisons are limited to ROI median volumes and non-significant group differences. Additionally, PTSD status is based on a low PCL-S threshold and very small case numbers, but the decisive exclusion is the absence of VBM/whole-brain coordinate results required by the review. Therefore it must be excluded.

Although the study includes adult PTSD and comparison groups and reports whole-brain structural MRI results, it does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The authors used FreeSurfer cortical thickness (surface-based) vertexwise analyses rather than VBM and did not report coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the key inclusion criterion requiring VBM methods and coordinate-based between-group VBM results.

Although the study uses whole-brain VBM and includes a PTSD subgroup (BPD+PTSD), it does not report a whole-brain VBM contrast comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed individuals without PTSD or to trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The reported between-group whole-brain comparison is BPD+PTSD vs BPD-PTSD (both groups have BPD), and it is unclear whether the BPD-PTSD group is trauma-exposed. There is no clear coordinate-based PTSD vs healthy control (or PTSD vs trauma-exposed non-PTSD) contrast in the paper. Thus it fails the requirement to report at least one whole-brain between-group VBM contrast comparing PTSD cases to an acceptable comparison group.

This study does not meet the VBM or whole-brain voxel-based morphometry inclusion criteria. It reports hippocampal subfield volumes derived from FreeSurfer automated segmentation (ROI-based volumetry of 10 hippocampal subfields) rather than voxel-wise, whole-brain VBM analyses, and no coordinate-based whole-brain between-group VBM results are reported. Although it includes adult PTSD and comparison participants (combat-exposed veterans), the imaging method and reported outcomes are region-of-interest volumetric analyses, violating the requirement for VBM coordinate-based whole-brain results. Therefore it must be excluded.

The study does not meet the primary imaging inclusion criterion: it reports cortical thickness analyses via FreeSurfer and resting-state functional connectivity, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. No whole-brain VBM coordinate-based between-group contrasts (PTSD vs trauma-exposed non-PTSD or unexposed controls) are reported. Although the sample includes adults with PTSD and trauma-exposed individuals, the morphometric methods and reported outcomes are not VBM-based, and results are presented as vertex-wise cortical thickness clusters rather than VBM coordinates. Therefore it fails the ‘VBM of gray matter’ and ‘whole-brain VBM results’ inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses MRI-based voxel-based morphometry and includes both a PTSD group and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group (adult sample), the reported VBM analyses are correlational (GMV correlated with a Sleep Disturbances Score) across the whole sample and within each group. The full text does not present coordinate-based, whole-brain VBM results from a between-group contrast directly comparing PTSD versus trauma-exposed controls (or versus trauma-unexposed controls). Because the review’s inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain VBM between-group comparison (with coordinate results), this study does not meet that criterion and must be excluded.

The study does not meet the VBM requirement: it reports surface-based cortical thickness analyses using FreeSurfer (vertex-wise cortical thickness), not voxel-based morphometry of gray matter volume or concentration. It also does not present whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing PTSD cases to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls; analyses are correlational/mediation within a trauma-exposed veteran sample (PTSD symptom severity), not between-group VBM comparisons. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter (SPM5 with DARTEL, modulated GM images) from T1 MRI; includes an adult PTSD group (n=16 after exclusions) and a trauma-exposed control group without PTSD (n=16); and reports whole-brain VBM between-group results (significant decreased gray matter volume in ventral premotor cortex and pregenual anterior cingulate in PTSD vs. trauma-exposed controls, p<0.05 FDR-corrected, with clusters described and shown in figures). Although ROI analyses for hippocampus/amygdala were also performed, whole-brain voxelwise results are reported, so the study is not ROI-only. Sample is adult and the paper reports between-group coordinate/cluster results. Limitations (small sample, no non-traumatized control group) do not preclude inclusion per the review criteria. Therefore include.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. It uses surface-based cortical thickness measures (FreeSurfer vertex-wise analyses) rather than VBM and does not report whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results. Although it includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed control group, it fails to meet the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM methodology and coordinate-based whole-brain VBM comparisons. Therefore it must be excluded.

The study uses whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume (SPM8/DARTEL) and reports cluster-corrected, FWE whole-brain results. Participant groups include recent-onset PTSD (n=10), trauma-exposed non-PTSD (n=10), and trauma-unexposed healthy controls (n=20). The paper reports between-group whole-brain contrasts (PTSD vs. normal controls: decreased left ACC; non-PTSD vs. normal controls: decreased pallidum and pulvinar) with corrected statistics, meeting the requirement for whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM comparisons. Participants are adults and analyses are not ROI-only, longitudinal-only, or treatment-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study does not meet inclusion criteria. It used surface-based cortical thickness analysis (FreeSurfer) and ROI/subcortical volume analyses rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The sample contains trauma-exposed (TE) participants and healthy controls but no identified PTSD group (only two TE participants exceeded an IES-R cutoff; no PTSD diagnosis group was included). The paper therefore provides no whole-brain VBM voxel-based between-group contrasts (PTSD vs TE or PTSD vs HC) or coordinate-based VBM results required by the review. Thus it must be excluded.

The study does not meet the key imaging inclusion criterion. It uses surface-based morphometry (cortical thickness estimation via CAT12 and Desikan–Killiany atlas) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration, and it does not report whole‑brain VBM coordinate-based between-group contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Although adult PTSD and healthy groups are included, the absence of VBM whole-brain results (coordinate tables/figures) means it fails the primary inclusion criterion for this meta-analysis.

The study does not meet the VBM inclusion criterion. It reports cortical thickness (surface-based FreeSurfer measures) and resting-state ALFF (fMRI) rather than voxel-based morphometry of gray matter volume/concentration. No whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results comparing PTSD to controls are reported. Although it includes adult PTSD patients and healthy (trauma-unexposed) controls, the primary required imaging method (whole-brain VBM with between-group voxelwise coordinates) is absent. Therefore it must be excluded.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports vertex-wise shape analyses of the hippocampus and amygdala using FSL FIRST (subcortical surface/ROI-based shape measures), not whole-brain VBM gray-matter volume or concentration. No whole-brain coordinate-based VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls are reported. Therefore it fails the primary imaging-method and whole-brain VBM result inclusion criteria.

This study uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of MRI gray matter volume and reports whole-brain between-group comparisons with coordinate-based results (right BA11/OFC coordinates and figures). The sample includes adults with cancer-related PTSD (n=14 at baseline; n=9 at follow-up), a trauma-exposed comparison group (breast cancer survivors without PTSD), and trauma-unexposed healthy controls, meeting the required group structure. Whole-brain VBM results (cross-sectional contrasts PTSD vs non-PTSD and PTSD vs healthy) are clearly reported in text, tables/figures, and coordinate peaks. Participants are adults (18–55 yrs). Although the study includes longitudinal follow-up, it also provides qualifying cross-sectional whole-brain VBM contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) analyses of gray matter volume using MRI (SPM8) in an adult sample of combat-exposed veterans. It includes an explicit PTSD group (n=13) and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group (n=15), and presents whole-brain between-group contrasts (PTSD vs. non-PTSD) with coordinate-based results and cluster statistics, as well as whole-brain regression analyses against CAPS symptom severity. It is not limited to ROI-only analyses, does not focus solely on treatment/longitudinal effects, and participants are adults. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain analyses. It reports ROI/segmentation-based volumetry of amygdala nuclei derived from FreeSurfer rather than VBM gray-matter concentration/volume with coordinate-based whole-brain contrasts. The primary analyses are continuous symptom-volume associations within trauma survivors (and some group ANCOVAs of total amygdala volume), not whole-brain VBM contrasts comparing PTSD versus trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls with reported coordinates. Therefore it fails the required imaging-method and whole-brain/coordinate-based result inclusion criteria.

This study uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter on 3T MRI and reports whole-brain VBM group comparisons (PTSD vs trauma-exposed non-PTSD controls) with coordinate-based results (Table 2 and figures). Adult participants (male survivors) include a PTSD group (n=10) and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group (n=10). Whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (patients < controls) are described and cluster-corrected coordinates are provided. The paper is not ROI-only, not longitudinal/treatment-only, and reports between-group VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed controls. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis despite a small sample size and cross-sectional design.

This study reports manual/automated volumetric ROI analyses (segmentation of amygdala, hippocampus, prefrontal cortex) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM). No whole-brain VBM analysis or coordinate-based between-group VBM results are reported (only ROI volumes and summary statistics). Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria requiring MRI VBM (whole-brain voxel-wise) results and coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD to controls. Other criteria (adult PTSD and comparison group) are met, but the lack of VBM/whole-brain coordinate results mandates exclusion.

Although the study includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group and reports whole-brain structural comparisons, its primary neuroimaging outcome is cortical thickness estimated via an improved Laplacian surface/voxel-based thickness method, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. While VBM-DARTEL was used for preprocessing/segmentation, no VBM voxel-wise gray matter volume/concentration results or coordinate-based VBM contrasts are reported. This therefore fails the inclusion criterion requiring measurement and reporting of VBM gray matter volume/concentration results. The study thus meets the exclusion criterion for using non-VBM morphometric methods (cortical thickness only).

This adult (ages 19–37) MRI study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume and reports whole-brain VBM results (FDR-corrected cluster-level; peak MNI coordinates and cluster size) showing decreased lingual gyrus GMV associated with self-blame and differences between PTSD and non-PTSD subgroups. The sample includes trauma-exposed women with PTSD (n≈25 above PCL-5 cutoff) and trauma-exposed non-PTSD subgroup as well as non-exposed controls, and the paper reports between-group comparisons (PTSD vs non-PTSD and NEC). Results are whole-brain, coordinate-based, and adults only. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, non-adult sample, or absence of PTSD group) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study does not meet the primary imaging-method inclusion criterion: it uses cortical-thickness analysis (FreeSurfer) and automated volumetry, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration, and it provides no whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results. Secondary sampling criterion is also not satisfied for the meta-analysis objective: the PTSD cases are comorbid with BPD (BPD+PTSD), not a PTSD-only group, and contrasts are between BPD subgroups and controls rather than between PTSD-only vs trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails to provide the required whole-brain VBM case-control contrasts comparing PTSD to appropriate comparison groups. All other exclusion criteria (adult sample) are met, but the two primary inclusion requirements are not, so the study must be excluded.

This is a longitudinal treatment study comparing two groups of PTSD patients (EMDR ‘recovery’ and supportive therapy ‘wait-list’), not PTSD versus trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls. Although the paper uses VBM (GM density) and reports whole-brain results, it only reports treatment/longitudinal effects among PTSD patients and lacks the required between-group contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed controls or unexposed healthy controls. This also falls under the exclusion criterion 'studies that only report treatment and longitudinal effects.' Therefore it does not meet the meta-analysis sample and comparison-group inclusion criteria.

This study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM); it uses automated ROI volumetry (FreeSurfer segmentation of hippocampus and amygdala) rather than whole-brain VBM analyses. No whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls are reported. Although a PTSD group is included, the imaging method and reported outcomes do not meet the meta-analysis requirement for VBM whole-brain voxelwise results; therefore it must be excluded.

This study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on MRI to compare gray-matter density between a PTSD group (n=12) and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group (n=12). Whole-brain VBM results are reported, including Talairach coordinates and T-scores for reduced gray matter in PTSD (e.g., bilateral insula, left medial frontal gyrus), satisfying the requirement for coordinate-based, whole-brain between-group contrasts. Participants are adults and the study is not ROI-only, treatment-only, longitudinal-only, or limited to non-adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study includes adult PTSD, trauma-exposed (TC), and trauma-unexposed healthy control (HC) groups, it does NOT report whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) results. Gray-matter analyses were performed using region-based morphometry (RBM) on 14 predefined ROIs (Neuromorphometrics atlas) rather than a whole-brain VBM/voxelwise analysis with coordinate-based results. The inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain VBM result comparing PTSD to TC or HC; the present paper only reports ROI-based regional volumes and ROI statistics. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain VBM’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

The study used optimized voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on T1-weighted MRI to measure gray matter volume/concentration. The sample includes adults with DSM-IV PTSD (drug-naïve) and an age-matched healthy control group (trauma-unexposed). The paper reports whole-brain VBM between-group comparisons (PTSD vs healthy controls) at baseline with MNI coordinates and cluster results (Table 2) and statistical maps, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM results. Although the paper also reports longitudinal treatment effects, it contains qualifying cross-sectional between-group VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-unexposed controls. No exclusion criteria (non-VBM methods, non-adult sample, lack of coordinate-based between-group contrasts) are violated.

This study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. Morphometry analyses are cortical thickness measures derived from FreeSurfer and ROI-based thickness analyses, not whole-brain VBM. The paper reports ROI-to-ROI functional connectivity (resting-state fMRI) and cortical thickness associations, without coordinate-based whole-brain VBM contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM voxel-wise results and whole-brain between-group VBM contrasts.

Although the study uses VBM of gray matter volume on adult PTSD patients and includes a comparison group of non‑traumatized healthy controls, the voxel-wise analyses were restricted to a combined hippocampus/amygdala mask (ROI-based analysis) rather than reporting whole‑brain VBM results. The review’s inclusion criteria require at least one whole‑brain voxel‑based morphometry contrast comparing PTSD to trauma‑exposed or trauma‑unexposed controls. Because the reported results are ROI‑restricted (hippocampus/amygdala mask) and thus meet the exclusion criterion for ROI‑only analyses, the study should be excluded.

The study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (FSL-VBM) analyses comparing an adult group with PTSD (comorbid PTSD/mTBI; N=21) to a trauma-exposed deployed control group without PTSD or mTBI (N=16). Whole-brain VBM results (TFCE-corrected, 5000 permutations) showing reduced bilateral anterior amygdala volume in the PTSD/mTBI group are described, and surface-based morphometry was used to corroborate VBM findings. The sample is adult (ages 18–45). Although the PTSD group is comorbid with mTBI, inclusion criteria required at least one PTSD group and at least one comparison group (met here), and comorbidity is not an exclusion in the stated criteria. The paper provides whole-brain VBM between-group results and links them to behavioral measures, satisfying the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This study used voxel-based morphometry (SPM12/CAT12) on high-resolution T1 MRI and reports whole-brain, voxel-wise results comparing adults with PTSD (n=57) to trauma-exposed non-PTSD adults (n=163). Whole-brain GM volume differences (e.g., reduced medial and middle frontal gyri in PTSD) are reported with coordinates/figures and corrected/uncorrected thresholds. Sample consists of adults, not treatment or longitudinal-only, and analyses are whole-brain rather than ROI-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for VBM whole-brain comparisons of PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls.

The study does not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM). Structural analyses used SIENAX for global tissue volumes and FSL FIRST for subcortical segmentation (region-based volumetry), along with ADC measures and PET; no whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts are reported. Although it includes an adult PTSD group and trauma-unexposed healthy controls, it fails the required inclusion criterion of reporting VBM-based whole-brain comparisons, so it must be excluded.

The study used surface-based morphometry (FreeSurfer cortical reconstruction: cortical volume, thickness, surface area) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The review’s inclusion requires VBM (voxel-wise) whole-brain results (coordinate-based between-group contrasts) comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Although the sample includes adult PTSD and deployed control groups and reports whole-brain surface/vertex-wise analyses, it does not provide voxel-based morphometry coordinate-based contrasts. Thus it fails the mandatory imaging-method criterion (non-VBM method) and must be excluded.

This is an adult VBM MRI study comparing 12 fire survivors with DSM-IV PTSD to 12 trauma-exposed (same fire) controls without PTSD. Methods use whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (SPM2) of gray matter with between-group contrasts; significant whole-brain VBM results (coordinates, SPM{t} maps, table and figure) are reported for PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls (left hippocampus, left ACC, bilateral insula). The sample is adult, not a treatment/longitudinal or ROI-only study, and between-group coordinate-based results are provided. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study performed optimized voxel-based morphometry and reports whole-brain gray matter volume correlations with childhood maltreatment within a sample of adult women with IPV-related PTSD, it does NOT include any comparison group (trauma-exposed without PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls) nor report between-group VBM contrasts comparing PTSD to controls. The meta-analysis requires studies that provide whole-brain VBM results from between-group comparisons (PTSD vs trauma-exposed or vs unexposed). This paper’s analyses are entirely within-group correlational and therefore do not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although the study performed voxel-based morphometry (VBM) and reports cluster coordinates comparing PTSD and control groups, the VBM analyses were masked and restricted to predefined ROIs (FreeSurfer-derived bilateral ROIs) rather than a whole‑brain, voxel-wise analysis. The meta-analysis inclusion criterion requires at least one whole‑brain VBM result comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma‑exposed or trauma‑unexposed controls. All other inclusion criteria are met (adult sample, PTSD group plus both trauma‑exposed and unexposed control groups, MRI VBM on grey matter), but because the VBM results are ROI‑masked and not whole‑brain, the study does not satisfy the required whole‑brain evidence criterion and should be excluded.

Although the study includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed resilient control group (meets sample criteria), and reports that total brain volume was measured using VBM, the paper does not report any whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or unexposed controls. The main neuroimaging analyses reported are region-of-interest (ROI) cerebellar volume measurements rather than whole-brain VBM coordinates. Per the review’s inclusion criteria requiring at least one whole-brain VBM result (coordinate-based or equivalent) comparing PTSD vs controls, this study does not qualify and must be excluded.

The study uses voxel-based morphometry methods (SPM8 segmentation, modulation, smoothing of GM and WM) on structural MRI and reports whole-brain voxel-wise mass-univariate results and multivariate SVM results. Sample includes adults: 50 PTSD, 50 trauma-exposed without PTSD, and 40 trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The paper reports whole-brain VBM comparisons (PTSD vs healthy controls; PTSD vs trauma-exposed without PTSD; trauma-exposed without PTSD vs healthy controls) with FWE-corrected findings and supplementary tables of regions/coordinates (Tables S3–S9). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (VBM measurement, appropriate groups, whole-brain voxel-based results). No exclusion criteria are met.

This study uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on MRI data to assess gray matter density and reports whole-brain VBM comparisons. The sample includes adult PTSD patients (combat-exposed twins with PTSD, n=18) and appropriate comparison groups: trauma-exposed veterans without PTSD (n=23) and combat-unexposed co-twins, satisfying the requirement for at least one PTSD group and at least one comparison group. The paper provides coordinate-based, whole-brain VBM results (Tables and Figures) for PTSD vs. trauma-exposed non-PTSD and reports Diagnosis × Exposure interaction results. It is not an ROI-only, treatment-only, pediatric, or non-PTSD study. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on 1.5T MRI to compare adults with child abuse–related complex PTSD (n=31) to matched healthy nontraumatized controls (n=28). It reports whole-brain VBM group differences (reduced GM in hippocampus, ACC, OFC and other cortical regions) with coordinates and statistical thresholds (including SVC for a priori ROIs and whole-brain exploratory results). Participants are adults (female) and the paper provides between-group voxelwise coordinate-based results comparing PTSD patients to trauma-unexposed healthy controls. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) as one imaging modality, it does not report whole-brain VBM between-group contrasts comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed without PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The analysis is a multivariate multimodal canonical correlation (mCCA) linking continuous measures (presence of mTBI, CAPS-IV PTSD severity, BDI-II depression severity) to fused imaging modalities; reported results are canonical correlation maps and associations/correlations with symptom severity and mTBI status rather than coordinate-based whole-brain VBM comparisons of PTSD vs control groups. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain VBM between-group result comparing PTSD to a control group.

This study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) analyses of gray matter using MRI and provides coordinate-based results (figures and coordinates) comparing an adult acute PTSD group (n=14) to a matched healthy control group (n=14). Participants are adults (18–65). The paper includes at least one between-group VBM contrast (PTSD vs trauma-unexposed healthy controls) reported at whole-brain corrected significance, meeting the meta-analysis inclusion criteria. It does not rely solely on ROI or non-VBM methods, does not focus only on treatment/longitudinal effects, and includes appropriate comparison group(s). Therefore it should be included.

Meets all inclusion criteria: adult sample (female, 18–33), uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on T1-weighted MRI, includes an PTSD group (11 victims of rape with PTSD) and two comparison groups (trauma-exposed without PTSD and trauma-unexposed healthy controls), and reports whole-brain VBM between-group results (significant clusters reported with MNI coordinates, tables and figures; threshold p<0.005, cluster>50). No exclusion criteria are met (not treatment-only, not ROI-only, reports coordinate-based between-group contrasts). Therefore study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed control group and reports whole-brain vertex-wise findings, it does NOT use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The imaging analysis is surface-based cortical thickness mapping using FreeSurfer (vertex-wise cortical thickness), not VBM. The inclusion criteria require VBM measures and coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or unexposed controls. Because the neuroimaging modality/analysis does not meet the required VBM criterion, this study must be excluded.

This study used a voxel-based morphometry (VBM-style) whole-brain analysis (FSL-VBM) of T1 MRI data and reports voxelwise gray matter volume reductions in PTSD patients versus healthy controls (adult sample: PTSD n=25, controls n=25). It clearly includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-unexposed healthy control group, performs whole-brain VBM with permutation testing and cluster correction, and reports regional results (figures and Table 3) comparing PTSD to controls. The methods, results, and tables provide whole-brain, coordinate/cluster-based between-group contrasts. No exclusion criteria (non-VBM method, ROI-only, pediatric sample, treatment-only effects) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study does not report voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain results. It used FreeSurfer cortical thickness measures (region-of-interest analysis of the caudal anterior cingulate/dACC) rather than VBM of gray matter volume or concentration, and reported ROI correlations rather than coordinate-based whole-brain contrasts. Thus it violates the inclusion criteria requiring VBM methods and at least one whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group VBM contrast comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Additionally, although it includes adult PTSD and healthy control groups, the ROI-only cortical-thickness approach places it within the exclusion criterion: “only region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with no whole-brain results.”

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. It uses surface-based morphometry (FreeSurfer) to measure cortical thickness (SBM), and reports cortical thickness results rather than VBM coordinate-based whole-brain gray matter volume/concentration contrasts. Although the sample includes PTSD, trauma-exposed non-PTSD, and healthy control groups and performs whole-brain cortical-thickness analyses, it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM methods/reporting; thus it must be excluded.

Study reports voxel-based morphometry (VBM) combined with MRS, directly measuring gray matter density. Sample includes adults with recent-onset PTSD (n=12) and trauma-exposed non-PTSD controls (n=12), meeting the required groups. The paper reports a whole-brain VBM finding: reduced left hippocampal grey matter density in PTSD versus trauma-exposed controls (described in the text/abstract). This is not an ROI-only study, includes between-group VBM contrast, and does not focus solely on treatment/longitudinal effects. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Does not meet key inclusion criteria. This paper used surface-based morphometry (cortical thickness via FreeSurfer), not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The sample consists of veterans with blast-related TBI (mild/moderate) and healthy civilian controls; although PTSD and depression symptom measures were collected, the study does not present a group of individuals diagnosed with PTSD nor a trauma-exposed without-PTSD comparison group, nor a PTSD vs control whole-brain VBM contrast. No whole-brain coordinate-based VBM results are reported. Therefore it fails the VBM modality requirement and the required PTSD vs comparison group contrasts and must be excluded.

The study does not meet the VBM and whole-brain coordinate reporting requirements. It used FreeSurfer volumetric segmentation and ROI-based analyses (hippocampus, amygdala, ACC, PFC) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter, and it reports region volumes rather than whole-brain voxelwise coordinates. Analyses primarily used continuous PTS symptom measures (and some exploratory discordant-twin comparisons) rather than between-group voxelwise contrasts comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails key inclusion criteria: (1) no VBM method, and (2) no whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group VBM results comparing PTSD vs controls.

Does not meet primary inclusion criterion: the study uses surface-based cortical folding measures (local gyrification index via FreeSurfer) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. Although it compares adult PTSD patients to healthy controls, it does not report whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results for any PTSD versus control contrast. Therefore it fails the required imaging modality/analysis criterion for inclusion in this VBM meta-analysis.

Full text provided is not accessible (embedded PDF only) so I cannot verify whether the study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM), included required comparison groups (PTSD vs trauma-exposed without PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls), or reported whole-brain coordinate-based VBM results. Title suggests PTSD with alcoholism but does not confirm VBM methods, sample composition, or whole-brain coordinate results. Because at least one mandatory inclusion criterion (VBM whole-brain coordinate results and comparison groups) cannot be confirmed from the available content, the study must be excluded. If full text or methodological details (methods/results/tables with coordinates) are provided, I can re-screen.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports region-of-interest volumetric analyses derived from FreeSurfer segmentation (normalized ROI volumes) and hierarchical regressions, not whole-brain voxelwise VBM results or coordinate-based contrasts. No whole-brain VBM coordinates or voxelwise between-group maps comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls are reported. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring MRI VBM whole-brain voxel-based results (coordinate-based) and must be excluded.

This study does not meet the meta-analysis inclusion criteria. It did not include a group of participants diagnosed with PTSD (only PTSD symptom severity was measured in IPV survivors), and the primary morphometric method was FreeSurfer surface- and ROI-based parcellation (volume/area/thickness across 160 Destrieux atlas regions), not voxel-based morphometry (VBM). The paper therefore does not provide whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results comparing a PTSD group to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Because it fails both the required imaging modality (VBM) and the requirement for an explicit PTSD group contrast, it must be excluded.

Although the study compares adults with PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD controls using structural MRI, it does not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. Instead, it uses intracortical similarity and single-subject gray-matter network graph-theory analyses (cube-to-cube correlations, AAL-normalized networks) and reports network topology and nodal metrics rather than whole-brain VBM voxelwise or coordinate-based volume/concentration results. Therefore it fails the essential inclusion criterion requiring VBM measurements and whole-brain VBM between-group results.

Does not meet VBM or PTSD sample requirements: This study uses FreeSurfer-derived cortical thickness and region-of-interest volumetry (surface-based measures), not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration, and it does not report whole-brain coordinate-based VBM results. The sample comparisons are HIV+/HIV− and interpersonal trauma (IPT) exposure groups, not participants diagnosed with PTSD versus trauma-exposed/no-trauma controls. Trauma is assessed as IPT history (not necessarily PTSD), and no PTSD group or PTSD-versus-control contrasts are reported. Therefore it fails multiple inclusion criteria (VBM method and PTSD group contrasts) and meets exclusion criteria (trauma studies not measuring PTSD and non-VBM methods).

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. It uses cortical thickness measures (FreeSurfer) and graph-theoretical structural network analyses, not VBM, and does not report whole-brain VBM coordinate-based between-group contrasts. Although it includes a PTSD group and healthy controls, the primary imaging modality/method does not meet the review’s required VBM criterion, so it must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: the study uses whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (CAT12/VBM on T1 MRI) to assess gray matter volume; includes adult groups with PTSD (n=27 after exclusions), trauma-exposed controls (TEC, n=33) and trauma-unexposed healthy controls (HC, n=30); reports whole-brain voxel-wise ANOVA and post-hoc VBM results comparing groups (significant bilateral hippocampus and left lingual gyrus reductions vs HC; results presented in figures/tables and described in text); not limited to ROI-only analyses; cross-sectional adult sample; coordinate/voxel-wise results are reported and thresholds described. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the paper should be included in the meta-analysis of structural brain alterations comparing PTSD, trauma-exposed non-PTSD, and trauma-unexposed controls.

The study used cortical parcellation/ROI volumetric analysis to compare pregenual ACC and subcallosal cortex between women with PTSD and trauma-exposed controls. It does not report voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain voxel-wise analyses or coordinate-based between-group results. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM whole-brain results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports surface-based cortical thickness measures derived from FreeSurfer, not whole-brain VBM gray matter volume/concentration results or coordinate-based contrasts. Although it includes adult PTSD and trauma-exposed control groups, it lacks VBM methods and coordinate-based whole-brain VBM comparisons required for inclusion; therefore it fails the primary imaging-method inclusion criterion. Additionally, while PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls are present, there is no trauma-unexposed control group reported for some contrasts. Exclude on methodological grounds.

This study used manual ROI volumetric tracing of the anterior cingulate cortex with Brains2, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM). Although it includes a PTSD group and unexposed healthy controls, it does not report any whole-brain VBM coordinate-based between-group results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM whole-brain results.

This is NOT a VBM whole-brain voxel-based morphometry study. The paper reports automated ROI volumetry (FreeSurfer) of amygdala and hippocampus volumes, not whole-brain VBM analyses or coordinate-based between-group voxelwise results. Although it includes adult PTSD and trauma-exposed control groups, it fails the required imaging-method criterion and falls under the exclusion of studies that only perform ROI analyses with no whole-brain VBM results.

The provided full-text excerpt does not include methods or results confirming voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter, nor does it report whole-brain, coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD patients to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Only title, author, funding and keywords (PTSD, MRI) are present. Because I cannot verify key inclusion criteria (use of VBM, presence of the required comparison groups, and whole-brain coordinate results), the study must be excluded.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. It uses surface-based cortical thickness measures and structural covariance (graph theory) analyses derived from cortical thickness (BrainSuite), plus ROI/voxel cortical-thickness comparisons—not VBM. The paper does include PTSD and control groups (and mTBI/comorbid groups), but it does not report whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring MRI VBM results/coordinate-based whole-brain VBM contrasts. Exclude.

Although this study compares adult PTSD patients (n=51) with healthy controls and uses MRI-based gray matter measures, it does not report whole-brain voxel-wise VBM coordinate results. The authors extracted regional gray-matter volumes from 114 atlas ROIs and performed hypothesis-driven analyses on 16 selected ROIs (ROI-based volumetry), with no coordinate-based, whole-brain VBM contrast reported. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain VBM result (coordinate-based).

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. It reports FreeSurfer-derived cortical thickness, surface area, and subcortical volumes and machine-learning classification (EPIC), not whole-brain VBM analyses or coordinate-based VBM results. Although it includes an adult PTSD group and trauma-exposed controls, it fails the primary inclusion criterion (VBM measurement and whole-brain voxelwise, coordinate-based results). Therefore it must be excluded.

This study used FreeSurfer-based hippocampal subfield segmentation (ROI volumetry) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM). Although it includes adult PTSD patients and trauma-exposed controls, it does not report any whole-brain VBM analyses or coordinate-based voxelwise between-group results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed groups. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring MRI VBM whole-brain results.

This study used voxel-based morphometry (SPM2 VBM) on T1-weighted MRI to assess grey matter volume, and directly compared adults with PTSD (n=21) to trauma-exposed controls (n=17). It reports whole-brain VBM results (family-wise error corrected and coordinate tables) showing reduced hippocampal and rostral anterior cingulate volumes in PTSD versus controls, plus whole-brain cluster results. The paper provides coordinate-based between-group contrasts and regression analyses (time since trauma vs hippocampal volume). It is cross-sectional, not treatment- or ROI-only, and includes adult participants. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain VBM comparisons of PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls.

This study does not meet the inclusion criteria. It did not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM); volumetric analyses were ROI-based using FreeSurfer (region-of-interest entorhinal cortex, frontal/temporal ROIs) rather than whole-brain VBM with coordinate-based results. The comparison groups are mTBI with PTSD symptoms versus mTBI-only (both brain-injured), not a PTSD group compared to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls as required. No whole-brain VBM results, coordinate tables, or voxel-wise comparisons contrasting PTSD vs control groups are reported. Therefore it fails the methodological (VBM) and sample/comparison-group requirements for inclusion.

This is a within-group VBM study of 23 mixed-gender patients with functional neurological disorder (FND) reporting volumetric associations with symptom severity, childhood abuse and PTSD symptoms. It does not include a diagnostic PTSD group nor a trauma-exposed without-PTSD or trauma-unexposed control group, and it does not report any between-group whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (coordinate-based results) comparing PTSD cases to a comparison group. Inclusion criteria require at least one PTSD group and at least one comparison group with whole-brain VBM between-group results. Because the paper only reports within-group correlational findings (and secondary analyses in female subset) rather than the required between-group coordinate-based comparisons, it does not meet the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis and should be excluded.

Although the study includes voxel-based morphometry (VBM) analyses of gray matter volume, it does not report whole-brain between-group VBM contrasts comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD participants or trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The VBM results are reported as continuous/regression associations between changes in gray matter volume and changes in posttraumatic anhedonia over time (longitudinal within-sample analyses), not as coordinate-based group contrasts. The sample also lacks a trauma-unexposed control group. Therefore it fails the requirement to report at least one whole-brain VBM between-group comparison of PTSD versus a comparison group and must be excluded.

The study did not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It measured hippocampal subfield volumes via automated FreeSurfer segmentation (ROI-based volumetry) on T1 MRI and reported subfield volume comparisons, not whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results. Although the sample includes PTSD, trauma-exposed non-PTSD, and healthy control groups, the methods do not meet the meta-analysis inclusion criteria requiring whole-brain VBM analyses and coordinate-based between-group contrasts. Therefore the study must be excluded.

Although this study uses voxel-based morphometry of gray matter and includes a PTSD group and healthy controls, the reported whole-brain VBM results and coordinate tables focus on ASD versus healthy controls and correlations within the ASD sample. The paper does not provide coordinate-based whole-brain contrast results comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD participants or to trauma-unexposed healthy controls (no PTSD vs HC or PTSD vs trauma-exposed coordinates are reported). Because the review requires at least one between-group whole-brain VBM contrast involving a PTSD group with coordinate-based results, this study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports Freesurfer-based automated regional volumetry (ROI measures of amygdala, hippocampus, ACC, etc.) normalized to ICV, not whole-brain VBM analyses or voxel-wise statistical maps. No coordinate-based whole-brain VBM results or between-group voxelwise contrasts comparing PTSD vs trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls are reported. Although the sample includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed (mTBI-only) comparison group, the primary inclusion criteria require VBM voxel-wise whole-brain results (coordinate-based), which this paper does not provide. Therefore it must be excluded.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain analyses. It reports manual hippocampal tracings, hippocampal surface/shape modeling, and FreeSurfer-based hippocampal subfield volumetry (ROI/subfield analyses), not whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based between-group VBM contrasts. Although it includes adult PTSD patients and healthy controls (and trauma histories), it fails to meet the required imaging modality and whole-brain VBM result criterion, so it must be excluded.

Study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports manually segmented ROI volumetry of hippocampus, amygdala, and parahippocampal gyrus and global volumetrics, not whole-brain VBM analyses or coordinate-based voxel results. Although it includes PTSD and trauma-exposed control groups, it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM whole-brain results; it therefore meets the exclusion criterion for ROI-only (non-VBM) studies.

This study does not meet the meta-analysis inclusion criteria. It used surface-based cortical thickness analysis (CIVET) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The sample includes only individuals with PTSD (no trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy control comparison groups reported), and analyses focus on within-PTSD correlations/prediction of recovery rather than between-group VBM contrasts. No whole-brain VBM coordinate-based between-group results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or unexposed controls are reported. Therefore it fails the VBM method requirement and the requirement for at least one between-group VBM contrast, so it must be excluded.

This study does not meet the inclusion criteria for the VBM PTSD meta-analysis. It does not include any group with PTSD (participants with PTSD were excluded by SCID; the sample compares depressed/nondepressed and trauma-exposed/nonexposed groups). Imaging methods are not voxel-based morphometry: analyses used FreeSurfer cortical thickness, hippocampal volumes, and DTI tractography/graph-theory connectomics rather than whole-brain VBM of gray matter volume/concentration. No whole-brain VBM coordinate-based between-group contrasts comparing PTSD versus trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls are reported. Therefore it violates required imaging modality and lacks the PTSD group, so it must be excluded.

This study used manual ROI volumetry of the hippocampus (absolute and percent hippocampal volume) from MRI, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It does not report whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM results or any voxelwise between-group contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Although the sample includes adult combat veterans with and without PTSD (so the participant groups are appropriate), the imaging method and lack of whole-brain coordinate results mean it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM and whole-brain voxelwise results.

The study uses surface-based morphometry (Freesurfer vertex-wise cortical thickness, cortical area, and cortical volume) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. Although it includes PTSD and trauma-exposed control groups and reports whole-brain vertex-wise results, it does not perform coordinate-based VBM analyses required by the review inclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion (VBM method) and meets the exclusion criterion (non-voxel-based morphometry methods).

This study does not meet key inclusion criteria. It is an open-label treatment pilot (pre-post) of phenytoin in nine PTSD patients without any comparison group (no trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls). MRI outcomes are volumetric measures (whole brain and hippocampal volume) from region/volume analyses and longitudinal change, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) with coordinate-based whole-brain results. Thus it lacks the required VBM method and between-group coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD to control groups. Additionally, it reports treatment/longitudinal effects rather than cross-sectional VBM group comparisons. Exclude.

Full text inaccessible (404 error), so methods and results cannot be verified. Title indicates focus on rostral anterior cingulate volume predicting treatment response to CBT in PTSD, suggesting a treatment/longitudinal and likely ROI-focused analysis rather than a whole-brain VBM comparison between PTSD and trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Cannot confirm presence of whole-brain VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts required by inclusion criteria. Given lack of accessible full text and likely mismatch with inclusion criteria (treatment-only focus and probable ROI analysis), exclude study.

The study does not meet the MRI modality inclusion criterion: it reports cortical thickness analyses using FreeSurfer (surface-based morphometry) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. No whole-brain VBM results or coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing PTSD (or PTSD-only) to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls are presented. Additionally, the primary PTSD group is comorbid with mTBI (PTSD + mTBI), complicating direct PTSD-only comparisons. Therefore it fails the requirement to report at least one whole-brain VBM between-group contrast, and is excluded.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports FreeSurfer-derived volumetric and surface-based shape (RD, JD) analyses of subcortical structures from T1 data, not whole-brain VBM of gray matter volume/concentration. Although a PTSD-only group is included, the paper does not present whole-brain voxel-wise VBM coordinate-based results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM methods and whole-brain voxel-based between-group results.

This study used manual hippocampal volumetry and FreeSurfer-based insula segmentation plus MRS; it did not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM) nor report any whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or unexposed controls. The outcomes are ROI/manual volume measures and spectroscopy, not whole-brain VBM contrasts. Therefore it fails the required imaging modality/whole-brain VBM criterion for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes voxel-based morphometry analyses, the structural comparisons are between FKBP5 genotype groups (TC/TT vs CC), not between PTSD cases and comparison groups. The MRI cohort consisted of traumatized women and the paper does not report any whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD participants or to trauma-unexposed healthy controls. Therefore it does not meet the requirement to report at least one whole-brain VBM result comparing PTSD vs an appropriate control group.

Imaging method does not meet inclusion criteria: the study used manual ROI volumetry (hippocampus and amygdala tracing) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain analysis. Although the sample includes adults with PTSD and both trauma-exposed and healthy control groups, the paper does not report any whole-brain VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts. Therefore it fails the essential requirement for VBM whole-brain/coordinate-based results and must be excluded.

This study is a psychotherapy treatment trial reporting pre- and post-treatment structural volumes in 20 PTSD patients (EMDR vs PE). It uses automated ROI volumetry (BRAINS-2) of amygdala and hippocampus rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM), reports no whole-brain VBM analyses or coordinate-based between-group contrasts, and includes no comparison group of trauma-exposed without PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls. It therefore fails multiple inclusion criteria (must use VBM and include at least one between-group PTSD vs control contrast) and meets exclusion criteria for studies reporting only treatment/longitudinal effects and ROI-only analyses.

Full text unavailable (404). Based on title and bibliographic info, this study reports hippocampus and amygdala volumes in borderline personality disorder (BPD) patients with or without comorbid PTSD — not a PTSD-focused sample. It likely uses region-of-interest volumetry rather than whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM). The meta-analysis requires VBM whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group contrasts comparing PTSD cases to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. This study does not clearly provide a PTSD vs control VBM whole-brain contrast (sample is BPD subgroups) and appears to report ROI volumes only. Therefore it does not meet the VBM whole-brain and sample inclusion criteria and is excluded.

Full text unavailable (API error returned). From title and bibliographic details, the study appears focused on hippocampal asymmetry in PTSD, suggesting an ROI/volumetric analysis of the hippocampus rather than whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM). No evidence in provided content of VBM methods, coordinate-based whole-brain results, or inclusion of both PTSD and trauma-exposed non-PTSD and/or trauma-unexposed control groups. Because the supplied full text is inaccessible and the available information does not meet the review’s required inclusion criteria (whole-brain VBM with coordinate-based between-group contrasts), I must exclude this study. If full text becomes available showing whole-brain VBM results comparing PTSD to appropriate control groups with coordinates, this decision should be revisited.

This study uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on MRI data to assess gray-matter volume and reports whole-brain VBM results (between-group contrast) comparing 9 PTSD patients to 16 trauma-exposed non-PTSD controls, including coordinate-based findings (left ACC peak at -8,12,32) and corrected statistical thresholds. Participants are trauma-exposed adults (Tokyo sarin-attack survivors). It directly addresses the review objective and meets all inclusion criteria (VBM method, PTSD group plus trauma-exposed comparison, whole-brain coordinate-based results). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, non-PTSD, non-adult sample, longitudinal/treatment-only) are violated.

Although this study uses VBM and compares a PTSD patient group with normal controls reporting whole-brain gray matter differences, the provided full-text information (abstract) does not report coordinate-based results for any between-group contrasts. The review’s exclusion criteria require coordinate-based results for at least one PTSD vs control contrast. Additionally, key methodological/sample details (e.g., MRI specifics, exact group definitions, ages) are not available in the supplied text to confirm all inclusion criteria. Because the necessary coordinate-based whole-brain VBM results are not documented in the provided content, I must exclude the study.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain analyses. It reports manual ROI volumetry of the olfactory bulbs (and hippocampal tracing) from T2 MRI, not VBM measures of gray matter volume/concentration, and provides no coordinate-based, whole-brain VBM results comparing PTSD vs. trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed groups. Thus it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM and whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group results. (Participants are adult and groups include PTSD and comparison groups, but the imaging method and reporting do not meet inclusion requirements.)

The study uses surface-based cortical thickness analysis (FreeSurfer) and longitudinal cortical thickness measures, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. Inclusion criteria require VBM whole-brain voxel-based results (coordinate-based contrasts) comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Although the study includes adult PTSD cases and healthy controls and reports whole-brain cortical thickness differences, it does not report VBM coordinate-based whole-brain gray matter volume/concentration results. Therefore it does not meet the required imaging method criterion.

This study reports bilateral MR volumetry of the amygdala in 11 chronic PTSD patients and examines right vs left amygdala volumes. It does not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain analyses, does not report coordinate-based whole-brain results, and does not include a between-group comparison of PTSD versus trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the VBM requirement, the whole-brain evidence requirement, and the requirement for at least one PTSD vs comparison-group contrast.
